lines.text: You just can't keep away from windows with bars, can you, Chick?
Oh, bars ain't half bad, Scrap Iron, not when you're on the outside lookin' in.
Hey buddy, would you give a poor man a dollar?
A dollar? You got a lot of nerve! If you'd asked for a dime or a quarter, I might have done something.

[Indignantly]
Say, listen, all I asked you is to give me a buck. You don't wanna give it to me, say so, but don't tell me how to run my business!

[laughing admiringly at his independent spirit]
That wins a dollar, beau!
[He tosses him the money]

[Brushing off Chick's suit]
Yes, suh, I sure Savannahed them folks out!
That so?
[Not realizing that the suit he's wearing has money in its pocket]
Well, the smallest thing I have is a twenty.

[Amused]
Boss, if I had change for that right now, I'd be attending a Southern girl lavishly!

[to Ruth]
Now, let's have a good look at you, Ruthie.
[Taking off her hat and obviously finding her attractive]
Well, well, the gentleman said. The more you see the more you wanna see.
I'm no pollyanna or sweet sixteen either. I've been around. I know what it's all about, but, gee, I always try to keep decent. There's a few things I draw the line on. Dr. Bernardi is one of them.
Go ahead. You got me interested. Then what'd he do?

Well, at first he said his eyes were bad, and he couldn't read, so he offered to pay me fifty cents an hour to read to him at night after work. Well, that was all right, but the kind of books he read...
[laughs]
Gee, I didn't know they printed them so bad. He said he got them in Europe.
Yeah? Yeah, I've seen the type in hotel lobbies lookin' up at balconies.

[to Chick]
Hey, I'd rather starve than eat those vagrancy beans again.

[Last lines]
Gentleman for a day.

[as they walk down the tracks]
C'mon. Let's get goin'.
Gee, what is it, a fiddle?

[holding a violin case]
No, a piano.
Oh, I beg your pardon. I thought you were someone else.
You're right. I am somebody else, but don't let that stop you. Sit down.
You aren't really a well kept woman till you've accepted at least three pair.
[of stockings]
And a bottle of Lily of the Valley.
I'm starvin' and you ask me riddles.

Riddles or not, I'm heading straight for a dining room with soft, soothin' music, a table sitting right next to a kitchen, a good lookin' waitress just strivin' to please. Say, how would you like, right now, a thick porterhouse steak, just smothered in onions? Brown potatoes bobbin' up and down in country gravy? A flock of hot biscuits and some honey on the side? A cut of raisin pie? And a cup of coffee? Could you go for that?
Please get this straight, I need the money. I need it badly and I wouldn't go with you...
Oh, sure, I know. You don't have to explain, honey, I've been around.
I've got to have 64 dollars and 50 cents. And I've got to have it now, tonight!
What's the 50 cents for? War tax?
If I don't get it, oh, I don't know what...
Oh, that's alright. 64 bucks is a lot of dough. But, I've got it, if that's what you mean.
I can't stand when anyone plays me for a sucker. Why, only a couple of minutes ago I walked out on a little tramp. The minute I saw you, I knew it was a conquest.
Now what's the matter?
Just hungry, I guess.
What you need is a little drinkie!
Are you one of them melancholy numbers? 'Cause if you are, the party's off right now.
No, I feel fine. Honest, I do.
Nobody's going to sing the blues around me! I got enough troubles of my own. Besides, you don't toss out 64 bucks every day, just to get in the dumpster!
Oh, don't be silly. I'll be alright. I just need a little drink.
I was broke and I had to do something. But, what can a chorus girl with a broken ankle do?
Say, you ain't turned gigolo, have you?
No. Still a sucker. Santi Claus in wolf's pajamas.
I bet you'd look like a million bucks in that dress. And I bet it don't even cost half that.
It's probably not my size.
Don't be so sure.
Anyway, we came here to buy stockings.
Nah, you'll get arrested, running around in nothing but stockings.

You're not going to gain a thing by stalling. You got them from Bushy Sloan. You're supposed to turn them over to the guy that's coming in from St. Louis on the number 6. Pretty slick mob. We were looking for a man down here and they've got a woman to meet the train. Well, come on, cough up.
I have nothing to tell you. I don't know anything about it.
Did he give you the dough?
[Referring to Chick]
No.
Don't you believe her. Sure, I gave her the sugar and here's more.
What did you do today, from noon on?
Well, at noon today, I was - I was in the city jail.
Yea, what for?
Vagrancy.
Chick?
What's wrong with you, sister?
Oh, lay off her, can't you! She just found out her Santi Claus was a hobo.
Alright, Mr. Wise Hobo, you win.
And your the bird that was going to sue the Government. Well, you better get lined up with a lawyer, Bushy, your washed up!
Gee, you're a swell guy, Chief. I don't blame you for not believing me. I don't believe myself sometimes.
Say, Chief, does that pass go for me too?
Sure. But, I ought to throw you in the hoosegow on general principals.
General who? I never heard of him.
It's going to be cold winter, hobo. Maybe you'll wish you were back at that hoosegow!
Say, I can always get in if I change my mind. Where I'm going, there ain't no winter. No snow. No ice. Nothing but palm trees and pineapples and beautiful gals singing love songs.
Call Ruby and tell her the fleet's in.
Call her yourself. I ain't invitin' no competition. I'm setting out to sea myself.

I did an examination for the Secret Service once. They've got a cinch with nothing to do but bumming around with the Government paying all their expenses. Riding around on soft, pullman cushions. Yeah, that's the kind of a job we ought to have.
What do you mean we? I'm satisfied here.
I don't mean you. I mean me and my fanny.
Oh, I didn't know you was married.
Why don't you be reasonable?
Oh, shut up.
Oh, come on, Sweetheart. I ain't like most sailors.
Then, I ain't interested.
[Walks away]

[Kisses Society Woman on the lips]
Goodbye... I'll wire you when I get to Reno.
There's a hotel clerk there who's really quite charming. His name's Rye. Give him my love.
lines.character: Society Woman Saying Goodbye to Jean

lines.text: Not me! I'm cured of giving men love.
